TEXT:
The pt. is a 30y/o M with unknown PMH found down after reported heroin
   use s/p cardiac arrest in the field. Per report EMS was called by a
   friend reporting the pt became unresponsive after heroin and EtOH use.
   The pt was found down after approx 10 minutes of unresponsiveness and
   he received 30 minutes of CPR with initial rhythm asystole followed by
   PEA. He received epi X2, atropine X2, HCO3 X2 and narcan 6 mg. He was
   intbated in the field. Pt initially taken to [**Hospital 2653**] Hospital where intial
   BP 58/22. Pt treated with IVF bolus and 2amp bicarb. Did not receive
   pressors as BP rose to 140 following IVF. Pupils were fixed and
   dilated. EtOH 265. Initial ABG 6.94/77/66/16. CT Head negative.
   .
   On arrival to the ED, vitals: HR 130, 150/100 and he was on the vent.
   Neurologic exam on arrival included pupils fixed and non-reactive at
   6mm. No withdrawal of extremities to pain. CXR showed ET in place. He
   was started on the artic sun protocol. 2 PIV placed and he was started
   on propofol for sedation. Initial ABG 7.41/24/172/16. Labs showed serum
   EtOH of 198. Serum benzo screen positive. The patient had no
   identifying information on arrival to the ED.
   .
    Events : patient is on artic sun protocol and patient was on propofol
   and patient was having jerking movements, therefore sedation changed to
   versed and Fentanyl and increased to versed 12mg/hr and Fentanyl
   250mcg/hr and started on cisatracurium TOF 0/4. UO 10-45ml/hr and BP
   170-180/109-112 with MAP 130-140, MD aware and continue to monitor.
   .H/O cardiac arrest
   Assessment:
   Post cardiac arrest from OSH, received patient from ED with artic sun
   protocol, in sinus rhythm, no ectopy
   Action:
   Artic sun protocol, core temp 34, goal temp 34, sedation changed from
   propofol to versed and Fentanyl and increased versed to 12mg/hr and
   Fentanyl 250 mcg/hr as patient had jerky movements and started on
   cisatracurium. TOF [**1-25**] on 10ma with cisatracurium of 0.1/mg/kg. Trend
   CE, repleted lytes
   Response:
   Sedated and paralysed, core temp 34, no shivering or jerky movements,
   continue on cisatracurium
   Plan:
   Continue artic sun for 18-24 hrs, keep sedated and paralysed, monitor
   lytes and labs
   Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**])
   Assessment:
   Received patient from ED sedated and vented, A/C mode, 450/12/5 and
   40%, bilateral air entry clear
   Action:
   Sedation changed to versed and Fentanyl and patient is paralysed, O2
   sats 100%. ABG
   Response:
   Unchanged
   Plan:
   Continue vent support until patient  is on artic sun, then wean
   sedation and assess for extubation
   Impaired Skin Integrity
   Assessment:
   Patient with severe psoriasis over both legs, elbows,  hands and
   abdomen
   Action:
   None
   Response:
   Plan:
   Obtain med list from family and start in AM
   Anoxic brain damage (Anoxic encephalopathy, Hypoxic ischemic)
   Assessment:
   Patient arrived to ED from OSH following cardiac arrest with GCS 3, rt
   pupil 4mm nonreacting, lt pupils surgical. patient received from ED
   with propofol and sedation changed to versed and Fentanyl
   Action:
   Sedated and paralysed for artic sun protocol
   Response:
   Patient sedated and paralyses, unable to assess neuro
   Plan:
   When patient is off artic sun protocol , start wean sedation and assess
   neuro check

69 yo man transfered from floor care with worsening resp distress & rapid a.fib. Pt was admitted to hospital [**2192-2-16**] pm with ^^ SOB(of 2 days), productive cough and fever to 102. Also reported malaise and diarrhea x2 episodes. Pt with + smoking history(quit ~ 3 yrs ago per pt). No official dx prior to this admission. CXR is c/w emphysema. CTA done to r/o PE..reported neg for PE but + for emphysema/bronchitis. No home meds. Pt states he notices wheezing at night at baseline.

PMH- BPH.. hytrin
     'fast HR"/ HTN.. toprol, cardura
     High cholesterol..lipitor

ALSO- h/o Polio as a child...weak right LE.. walks with cane & reports poor balance.
       nasal reconstruction
       s/p appy
       contracture to left elbow r/t old fx

Allergy- PCN.."breaks out"

No ETOH/recreational drug abuse.

Social- lives with wife; has supportive brother/sister-in-law
        retired technician
        no regular exercise.

Pt on R/O flu protocol and is on DROPLET precautions...need mask
..intial nasal swabs are negative for flu. (Had FLU shot..? when); nasal cultures are PND for flu. Blood cultures pnd. Pt started on levoquin prophylaxis and steroids for acute exacerbation COPD ??r/t flu vs pna.

New AFIB to rate 170's..? assoc with nebulizer rx. EKG reported as demand ischemia. serial CPK's done; neg troponin. No c/o CP. Rapid rate treated with diltiazem, then lopressor with temp effect. ASA started.
** heparin drip(weight based) started this am.

Pt transferred to ICU following recurring rapid afib and worsneing resp distress.

SEE careview for specific details regarding vital signs/interventions/ and response to therapy.

[**Name (NI) **] pt is awake/oriented/MAE's and follows commands. He is coperative but nervous with increasing anxiety noted throughout afternoon..probably assoc with stress of situation and ongoing resp distress. No c/o CP. C/O occ nausea & abd discomfort. Pt exhibiting intermittent shaking/tremores.

CVS- stable bp. afib with varying rates, and transient breaks to nsr. Diltiazam drip started & increased to 15mg/hr with transient effect in lowering hr & with occ conversion to nsr. NO VEA.
..IVF at 125/hr
..serum k+ 3.9..20 meq given ivp over 2/hr peripherally.
..arterial line placed for contniuous monitoring/anticipated frequent blood draws.

Resp- NRB at 15L with RR in 20's with NO c/o sob/acute distress. Pt using accessory muscles, but able to speak in full phrases/sentences.
Breaths sounds are distant with prolonged exp phase with wheezing throughout. Sats maintained at >95%. Initial abg within acceptable range. Congested cough.
Attempted to resume BIPAP..pt did not tolerate: became agitatd & c/o not being able to breathe. HR & BP elevated in respnse to distress &* anxiety. Pt pulled off mask & resfused to resume BIPAP. NRB replaced with almost immediate settling of pt 's distress.
MICU rsident discussed with pt need to resume BIPAPA in atempt to avoid intubation.. pt continued resistent to these measures- becoming anxious just talki

TITLE:
   Initially admitted [**3-2**] for planned potential diaphragmatic resection
   and reconstruction. [**3-3**] ex lap, to [**Hospital Ward Name 790**] 10 post-op. Today [**3-5**] while
   receiving 2nd unit PRBC, temp 102, O2 84% RA. ? As to if pt was having
   a transfusion reaction so transfusion rxn initiated and blood stopped.
   Placed on 2L w/O2 77% >> NRB 98%. Remained A&Ox3. ST to 120s. RR 22-30.
   SBP stable. Transferred to SICU for closer monitoring as pt w/? PE.
   PMH/PSH: Kidney stone/calculi. Ovarian CA. Aneurysm brain coiling [**2170**].
   [**10-29**]: exp lap, pelvic mass resection w/extensive tumor debulking,
   TAH/BSO, ileocecetomy, rectal resection w/colostomy/Hartmanns pouch.
   DVT.
   Hypoxemia
   Assessment:
          A&Ox3. Normal strength MAE. Pleasant and cooperative. Mild
   c/o abdominal/incisional pain. Using Dilaudid PCA as needed.
          O2 Saturation 100% on NRB. Denies SOB or WOB. LCATB slightly
   diminished in bases.
          ST with HR up to 115. Afebrile. Tmax 99.6.
          ? PE from events on floor.
   Action:
          Weaned NRB to 4L NC. Arterial line attempted by Dr [**First Name (STitle) 4031**]
   and Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 5728**].
          TTE obtained. LENI ordered for AM. Pneumatic boots on.
          Started on Heparin drip at 800 units/hr. Monitoring PT/PTT.
          Started on Vancomycin.
   Response:
          Continues using Dilaudid PCA appropriately.
          Unsuccessful in arterial line placement.
          Sat
s remain > 95% on 4L NC. LCTAB. RR 20. No increase WOB
   or c/o SOB.
   Plan:
          F/u results from TTE. Obtain LENI today.
          Monitor PT/PTT titrating Heparin drip to goal.
          Obtain AM ABG.
          Monitor pain/comfort. Continue PCA.

T/SICU Nursing Admission Note
55 male admitted to T/SICU in respiratory distress from [**Hospital Ward Name 36**] 7. Pt is POD 2 from EGD, lap nissen converted to open laparotomy, gastroplasty, fundiplication and ventral hernia repair. He has had poor pain control and is followed by the acute pain service. As a result, he had poor mobility and pulmonary toileting, and has developed a large right pleural effusion with subsequent lobular collapse. There is also concern for pneumonia. He was transferred here for pulmonary care and a thoracentesis was performed with pigtail insertion at the bedside. He has required high-flow neb oxygen and albuterol/atrovent nebs.

Neuro: A&Ox3, anxious at baseline, rx ativan for calming effect.

Pain: Complains of [**2116-7-11**] pain from the epigastric/incisional area radiating rightward and upward to the axilla. Epidural bolused and reevaluated by pain service, has small sensory level at T8. Not using PCA to max despite frequent reorientation, requiring fentanyl in addition for breakthrough pain.

Resp: Presented with stridor; lung fields are coarse but has intermittent upper airway expiratory wheezes which have responded well to frequent albuterol/atrovent nebs. Placed on high flow neb at 100% and weened to 50%. For collapse plan to start NIV overnight. Uses IS to 750 but not appropriately, when re-educated states "I know, I know" but will not listen to instructions.

CV: Sinus rhythm without ectopy. Strong palpable distal pulses. Periphery warm and well perfused. Frequently diaphoretic. EKG done. Pneumoboots and heparin sc ppx.

GI: Abd obese, tender at the incision, bowel sounds present, npo per 1* team.

GU: Foley to gravity drains clear yellow urine qs; plan to give lasix.

Endo: RISS with coverage as ordered.

Lytes: Ok from floor this am.

Skin: Intact; steristrips to abd incision.

Social: Lg family, multiple visitors, appropriate and supportive.

Plan: Maintain safety; pain management; pulmonary toileting; NIV; diuresis; abx; ?transfer to floor in am.

   Assessment and Plan
   24 year old man with a history of episodic dizziness, h/o pneumothorax
   who was admitted for fever and hypotension that responded to fluid
   resuscitation.
   1) Fever, up to 103.6. Associated with sore throat, rhinorrhea,
   headache, and nausea. No signs of meningismus, no leukocytosis.
   Questionable pathcy opacity in left lower lobe on CXR. U/A negative,
   blood cx pending. No LP. Although viral URI/ influenza is the most
   likely cause, the differential diagnosis includes  pneumonia and
   meningitis. The suspicion for bacterial meningitis is low given
   generally nontoxic appearance and lack of clinical symptoms. However,
   he declined an LP and was subsequently started on ceftriaxone and
   vancomycin empirically for meningitis. If another sources can be
   confirmed, these antibiotics can likely be discontinued. A repeat CXR
   can lend insight into the possibility of PNA.  If PNA is suspected, we
   can collect a sputum culture. In the meantime, we can D/C vancomycin,
   continue cetriaxone and start azithromycin for empirically for
   community-acquired PNA. Although elevated fever and hypotension
   potentially meet a SIRS picture, the response of his hypotension to
   fluid resuscitation and his history of poor PO intake make septic
   vasodilation less likely than volume depletion.
   -Repeat CXR to evaluate for PNA.
   -D/C
   -Follow up blood cultures.
   -If fevers continue to spike and alternate source is not identified,
   revisit option of LP with the patient and continue empiric treatment
   for meningitis.
   2.) Hypotension. As per above, differential includes vasodilation in
   association with SIRS vs. volume depletion but his response of his
   hypotension to fluid resuscitation and his history of poor PO intake
   make septic vasodilation less likely than volume depletion.
   -IVF for SBP<100
   -
   3.) Hypophosphatemia to phosphate 0.6.

Chief Complaint:  Lightheadedness
   Reason for MICU admission: Hypotension
   HPI:
   This is an 84 yo M with a past medical history significant for multiple
   myeloma (gets care at DF), on dexamethasone, who presents to the ED
   today with complaints of weakness and fatigue for several days. He does
   not endorse any localizing symptoms, but notes that he is "not feeling
   well" and feels weak. He describes that he had a near syncopal event
   yesterday. He describes that he was about to leave his home and
   suddenly fell. He did not have his walker with him. He endorses a
   prodrome of lightheadedness and felt "woozy" but denies loss of
   consciousness.  He did scrape his right knee and side of the face a
   little bit. He saw his gerontologist the same day, but felt better by
   that time. He describes possible fever/chills at home, but did not
   measure his temperature. He denies any n/v/d, sick contacts, myalgias,
   chest pain, palpitations or headache. He is complaining about severe
   sweating that occurs at night without any reason for which he had a
   work up at the VA that was unrevealing.
   Upon arrival to the ED, initial vital signs were 98.2 80 80/43 20 98%
   on room air. Tmx was 99.7. Exam was nonlocalizing with a benign
   abdominal exam. His lactate was 1.3, but labs were otherwise
   significant for a leukocytosis to 26,000 with a left shift, acute renal
   failure with a creatine of 2.3. He had a normal cxr, neg UA.
   Blood/urine cx were drawn and he was given 3L of NS with little
   improvement in his blood pressure. ECG was without acute change, and a
   troponin was elevated at 0.44, prompting a cardiology consult who
   advised that this was likely in the setting of ARF and hypotension and
   was not ACS. He was given an aspirin. At this time, the concern for
   relative adrenal insufficiency was raised and he was given a dose of
   stress dose hydrocortisone, with subsequent improvement in his BP to
   88/39. He was mentating clearly throughout.
   He is being admitted to the MICU for hypotension. At time of transfer
   to the MICU, his vitals were 73 88/39 20 96%ra, but he subsequently
   dropped his pressures to the 60
s. A CVL was placed, he was started on
   levophed and given a dose of vanco, CTX and flagyl. He now has a CVL
   and 2 18g PIV's for access, and has been started on his 4th L NS.
   Upon arrival to the ICU, the patient is alert and talkative. He feels
better
. He notes that he always has some amount of shortness of
   breath, and although he appears somewhat breathless, he will not
   endorse that this is any worse from his baseline. He denies pleuritic
   chest pain, palpitiations.

   The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is moderately

   examination. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The

   ECG: No acute STTWC
   Assessment and Plan
   84 yo M with history of MM, DVT, admitted with hypotension and ARF.
   #. Hypotension - Patient is afebrile, with a leukocytosis and no
   localizing symptoms. Hypotension was refractory to 3L of NS. Elevated
   WBC could be from dexamethasone, but there is a left shift and a mild
   bandemia. Suspicion is for occult infection compounded by poor PO
   intake and relative adrenal insufficiency in the setting of chronic
   steroid use. Other possibilties include PE, but no shortness of breath
   or tachycardia; cardiogenic shock is unlikely, as troponin elevation is
   less likely ACS and more likely the result of ARF and hypotension. As
   for source of possible sepsis, patient does not have any localizing
   symptoms. He is s/p CCY, UA is unremarkable, CXR is clear, abdominal
   exam is benign, no rashes. Given that he is relatively
   immunocompromised, it could be bacterial, atypicals or perhaps viral or
   fungal infection leading to poor PO intake and dehydration and actually
   not sepsis at this point. ?influenza, but no characteristic symptoms.
   - continue stress dose steroids for now
   - continue IVF aggressively overnight with caution for his history of
   valvular dysfunction
   - maintain CVP>10-12 mmHg, MAP>65
   - measure CvO2 sat
   - continue broad spectrum abx with vanco, zosyn, azithro
   - hold home anti-hypertensives until hemodynamically stable
   - r/o flu
   #. ARF - likely prerenal azotemia. IVF overnight. If BUN/Cr continue to
   rise, will send urine lytes.
   #. Leukocytosis - either secondary to infection or perhaps due to
   dexamethasone. Will hold off on antibiotics until there is a clear
   source or if patient decompensates.
   #. Elevated troponin - no EKG changes. This is likely in the setting of
   hypotension and ARF. Can complete ROMI, but low probability for ACS.
   #. Multiple Myeloma - multiple myeloma for which he takes dexamethasone
   weekly on a regular basis.  He gets most of his medications as well as
   labs done at the VA and his oncologist is at [**Hospital3 **].  He recently
   has been having problems with pain in his back and legs.
   #. History of DVT- continue coumadin
   #. Depression - continue citalopram
   #. Benign prostatic hypertrophy - continue finasteride at nighttime.

Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   75yo woman with ESRD on HD, HTN, BAD, some cognitive impairment /
   Parkinsonianism who apparently became upset about her HD (something
   related to interpersonal issues at the center at which she gets HD?)
   and missed at least 2 sessions of HD. The PCP was called by the family
   who recommended that the patient be sent to the ER given she had missed
   several sessions of HD. In the ER she was seen by Psych, cleared from
   their perspective, and was admitted to Medicine for further treatment
   and eventual HD. Also in the ER her SBP was in the 200-220s. K was 6.1;
   EKG with peaked Ts. Given calcium chloride.
   On the floor, SBP remained markedly elevated (SBPs in the 250s) and was
   tachypneic. Given 10mg of Hydralazine but didn
t respond. Given the
   hypertension and tachypnea she was admitted to the MICU. On arrival to
   the MICU she was given Labetalol IV with little effect and a Nitro gtt
   was initiated with good response. This was weaned off over the course
   of the night.
   She did remain tachypneic in the MICU. ABG revealed 7.45 / 45 / 497.
   She was on BiPAP but still tachypneic. Renal was consulted and
   evaluated the patient. They felt that dialysis was indicated but could
   not coordinate this acutely; she was intubated in the interim for
   persistent respiratory distress in the setting of volume overload and
   an expected delay in dialysis. Her settings were 450 / 18 / 5 / 40%;
   repeat ABG
   She remains sedated on Fentanyl gtt and intermittent Versed boluses.
   Her SBP has come down over the course of the evening to the 120-130s on
   these meds. K has remained persistently elevated from 6.2-6.5 and she
   received insulin / glucose and more calcium chloride.

   Assessment and Plan
   75yo woman with HTN, ESRD on HD, and other issues who is here after
   having missed at least two sessions of HD over the course of the past
   week presenting with profound hypertension and volume overload.
   Developed respiratory failure requiring intubation and mechanical
   intubation.
   1)       Respiratory failure: Intubated for increased work of breathing
   in the setting of volume overload. Her pH was a bit low this morning so
   her tidal volume was increased to 550, she continues to overbreath the
   vent. Would recheck an ABG this morning to follow pH, CO2. Hope to wean
   from ventilator after HD today
 the primary mechanism of her
   respiratory failure appears to be volume overload.
   2)       Hypertension: Improved with Fentanyl, Versed and intubation.
   Holding other antihypertensives at this time given her SBPs have
   decreased to the 130s. Would back off on the sedation in anticipation
   of potential extubation today. Goal SBP 130-180s.
   3)       Hyperkalemia / ESRD: plan for HD today. Hope to be able to
   wean respiratory support after HD. Would recheck K this morning given
   that it was 6.5 with AM labs. Continue Renagel, calcium carbonate.
   Appreciate Renal assistance.
   4)       ID: No clear e/o systemic infection, however, her CXR is
   striking for asymmetric opacification on the right compared to the
   left. This certainly could be asymmetric volume overload however
   infection is also a possibility (aspiration in the setting of
   intubation.) No plans for empiric antibiotics at this time. Will send
   any sputum for culture. Monitor for fevers. Will check CXR after HD.
   5)       Psych: Continue home anti-psychotics. Psych to see after
   extubation.
   6)       GI: No active issues. Stress ulcer prophylaxis after
   establishing oral feeding tube.
   7)       Code: Presumptively full. Dispo: MICU for now.

   glyburide for now.

   renal function. Would give 500 cc bolus of NS now and follow urine
   output and potassium.

   transient obstruction with normal LFT's. Continue to monitor. Patient
   is hungry with no abdominal pain, which makes acute pancreatitis
   unlikely.

   ECG in AM.

Recieved pt this am on 100% NRB mask. Pt confused, lethargic, but hypertensive at 160's/90's and tachycardiac 120-130's. On CIWA with 730am score 17. Had episode X 1 of irregular rhythm with PAC's, and PVC's. continued to decompensate despite nebs and 40mg Lasix (?CHF exacerbation), and 8mg Ativan. Required intubation d/t declining resp status, pending EGD and ETOH withdrawl. Pt placed on AC 500/12/100/17 and sedation changed to continuous Ativan gtt. recieved additional 1unit RBC (2units total since admission), resulting in HCT of 30.5. no s/s of GI bleeding, no stool or emesis. EGD done, unremarkable. no s/s of UGIB seen. Pt also had right pleural effusion tapped, resulting in 600cc fluid out. Afebrile.

ROS-

CV- NSR with occ PVC'c. rate 80-130's, BP 110-160/60-90, increasing with agitation. very poor circulation to RLE. radial pulses palpable. EF 25% (from previous echo). Pt continue to be r/o MI, monitoring enzymes. CPK elevated at 445. K at 1300 3.1, repleated with 40meq. Hct at 1300 30.5. repeat hct pending.

RESP- after EGD done, pt's vent changed to PS 5/ peep 5/ 50% with o2 sats 93-96%. f/u abg pending. Insp and exp wheezes. Pt on scheduled nebs. LS's improved since am lasix. suctioning sm amt stringy secretions.

GI/GU- NGT pulled when EGD done. may place NGT if needed. otherwise pt is NPO. hypoactive BS's. no stool. foley draining approx 50-250cc/hr clear yellow urine.

ID- afebrile. multiple cultures pending. remains on Levo and Clinda for ?asp PNA. MRSA precautions, cultures sent.

SKIN- multiple skin tears on left arm. covered with DSD. abrasions to right leg. pressure ulcer present on L buttocks.

ACCESS- RIJ TLC, Right A-Line, sharp. pt also has PIV X 1 in left forearm.

SOCIAL- no contact with family. Spoke with pt's PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] that pt has very minimal social contacts.

PLAN- monitor fluid balance, keep neg. monitor effects of decreased sedation and vent changes. plan to intubate when sedation weaned down. follow q 4hrs HCT and cardiac enymes. provide calming, safe environment while withdrawing from ETOH. resume CIWA and prn ativan as appropriate.

   An 84 year old lady with hypotension and radiographic evidence of
   pneumonia now two days out from rehab after a CABG. She is comfortable
   at this time.
   1. Hypotension: Has not required pressors.  Most likely source seems to
   be hypovolemia.
   - stop heprin
   - continue antibiotics
   Possible etiologies of hypotension include poor PO intake and
   hypovolemia (as supported by history) or sepsis from a Pneumonia as
   supported by elevated WBC and radiographic findings.  Levaquin already
   administed in ED and she is on her 3rd Liter of NS at the time of this
   note.  Non-invasive blood pressures difficult to obtain due to
   tremulousness. She is making ~ 20mL urine per hour.  Other
   possibilities include recent MI or possible PE or obstructing renal
   stone causing pyelonephritis.
   - Broaden antibiotic coverage to Vanc/Cefepime now, renally dosed.
   Cipro to start in 48 hours
   - Rule out Flu with DFA; precautions
   - Sputum cultures
   - Continue NS to urine output and goal SBP >100; MAP>65
   - Monitor BPs this AM, place arterial line (technically challenging
   given tremor) if monitoring becomes difficult or BPs remain low
   - Regular heart healthy diet
   - Hold metoprolol, Lisinopril and Lasix & amiodarone
   - Start heparin gtt, LENIs, VQ Scan
   - Echo
   - Renal U/S
   2. (HC vs. Hospital Acquired) Pneumonia: The patient has radiographic
   evidence of a RLL PNA, HAP versus HCAP given history with associated
   left sided pleuritic pain.  She denies cough or fever.
   - Vanc/Cefepime/Cipro as above
   - ABG to monitor respiratory status although she is satting well and
   not dyspneic
   3. Delirium with tremulousness: The patient has developed waxing and
   [**Doctor Last Name 533**] mental status in the past 24 hours per family report.  She has
   also developed new tremor at this time.  Her tremulousness can be due
   to new medications (Compazine) or neurontin overdose in the setting
   over worsening renal failure.  A possible neurontin overdose could also
   explain her worsening nausea.
   - Treat underlying infection as above
   - Hold compazine and neurontin
   4. Acute on Chronic Renal failure: The patient's Cr is elevated to 2.8
   with a baseline of 1.1-1.2, still elevated based on her size, weight
   and age.  Likely causes include pre-renal from poor PO intake or ATN
   from hypotension.  Worsening renal failure and subsequent neurontin
   overdose could also synergistically cause her renal failure.
   - Fluid rescussitation, PO Intake
   - [**Hospital1 7**] electrolyte monitoring
   - Repeat U/A with electrolytes and Urea
   - Renally dose meds
   - Hold Lisinopril and Lasix
   5. Anemia: A pre-operative baseline, but worriesome for
   hemoconcentration. Guaiac negative, no signs of bleeding or hemolysis
   given normal LFTs, but thrombocytosis concerning. Normal B12 in
   [**Month (only) 539**]

   - Hold Amiodarone given hypotension

   Assessment and Plan
   75 yo F with CAD, diastolic HCF, HTN, OSA who presents with lethargy
   and hypercapneic respiratory failure.
   .
   # Hypercapneic respiratory failure: Hypercarbic on ABG and decreased
   respiratory rate likely secondary to narcotic overdose given pt was
   sedated but woke up with narcan and was on narcan gtt.  This was
   stopped later the evening of admission. Pt had not signs of opioid
   withdrawal.  No opioids on tox screen but oxycodone does not always
   show up on screen.
   -decrease sedating meds by d/c percocet and renally dosing gabapentin.
   Supplement with Tylenol for pain control.
   -continue albuterol and ipratropium nebs
   -continue CPAP at night
   -no need for psych consult as not intentional over dose
   -consider SW consult to look into med administration and to address
   multiple admission.
   .
   # Lethargy: Most likely [**2-12**] narcotics overdose given positive urine and
   serum levels (including acetaminophen from percocet), and response to
   narcan. Also, may be component of hypercapnia.  Pt had no meningeal
   signs, fever, leukocytosis to indicate meningitis. No LP was done.  [**Month (only) 8**]
   also be [**2-12**] uremia with increased BUN/Cr.  CT of the head was negative
   for bleed.
   .
   # Leukocytosis: WBC elevated to 12.4 which is new since [**4-21**]. Pt was
   afebrile.   CXR was negative. Pt was treated for UTI during recent
   admission however UA was + for only trace leukocytes, few bacteria, mod
   bili, and trace ketones.  No current diarrhea and abd exam benign. WBC
   normalized by the morning after admission and no antibiotics were
   started. She is at higher risk [**2-12**] immunosuppression from steroids
   given treatment for RA. Also has eosinophilia of unknown etiology and
   should have further work up as outpatient.
   -f/u urine cx
   -obtain blood cx
   -trend eosinophils
   .
   # Acute on chronic diastolic CHF: Was hypervolemic on exam on admission
   but her CXR was without symptoms of pulmonary edema.  However,  patient
   has never had CXR signs of fluid overload in past admissions for
   decompensated CHF. She has an elevated proBNP.  Pt got 40 IV lasix in
   the ED with good output.  Her dry weight is 230 but she was 242 after
   discharge on [**4-21**].  Weight on admission was 246kg.  Current oxygen
   requirement is 2L NC.  She was diuresed while in the ICU.
   -diuresis goal 3-4 L today
   -no ACE as history of hyperkalemia
   -TTE to reassess change in cardiac function
   -can consider cards consult if other workup negative
   .
   # acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Her baseline Cr is likely 1.5.
    On [**4-21**] her creatinine was 2.2.  On admission her creatinine was 3.4
   which trended down to 2.3.
   -trend creatinine especially given continuing diuresis
   .
   # Tylenol overdose: Likely from tylenol component of Percocet
   indicating increased use of narcotics contributing to lethargy above.
   She has no known liver disease in past. Her Tylenol level did not
   require NAC or activated charcoal.
   - pt likely will need Tylenol for pain control and thus needs good
   teaching prior to discharge
   # OSA and mild obstructive lung disease: On CPAP at home [**12-15**].
   -Continue CPAP when sleeping
   .
   # CAD s/p MI and stent:  Pt CKs trended up and then down.  Troponin
   peak at 0.04.  MB index was positive. EKG was unchanged from prior.
   Likely demand ischemia in setting of hypercarbic respiratory therapy.
   -monitor on telemetry
   -restart ASA, statin, beta blockers
   ..
   # anemia: HCT at baseline.
   .
   # DM2:
   -ISS
   .
   # depression:
   -continue citalopram
   .
   # hypothyroidism:
   -continue synthroid
   .
   # rheumatoid arthritis/neuropathy/shoulder pain:
   -see above for pain control
   .
   # FEN:
   -low salt/diabetic & fluid restriction to 1L daily
   -replete k>4, mg>2 and check afternoon lytes given diuresis
   .
   # PPX:
   -heparin SQ for DVT ppx
   -PPI per home reg
   .
   #. Social issues: Patient with multiple hospitalizations in last year,
   unclear social situation at home, but should work on addressing this
   cycle of admissions - providing support, or address rehab/care issues
   - SW consult
   .
   # Code: Full code confirmed, ICU consent signed by daughter
   .

   and deeply sleeping between exams. Pt most currently alert, oriented x2

   34 yo male with hypertension and known h/o EtOH abuse p/w chest pain x
   3 days. Pt reports being sober since his admission in [**5-18**] for EtOH
   withdrawal and displaced left humeral fracture but reports resuming
   heavy EtOH use 8 days ago in the setting the drowning death of 15-yo
   daughter from a diving accident on [**8-18**]. He reports drinking
   approximately 2 pints of vodka daily for the past 8 days with his last
   drink was reportedly Friday night. Pt developed left chest pressure 3
   days ago accompanied by diaphoresis, nausea, shortness of breath, and
   left arm pain; no lightheadedness. He reports being at rest when this
   occurred although he was upset about his daughter's death. He presented
   to the ED for ongoing chest pressure. He was given ASA 325mg by EMS as
   well as NTG x 2 with some relief.
   .
   In ED, VS on arrival: T100.2, HR 117, BP 124/88, RR 18, O2sat 9% RA.
   In the ED, patient reported to have a brief unresponsive episode with
   quick recovery. ECG in ED initially with sinus tachy to 106 with
   question of isolated ST depression in III. CXR with low lung volumes.
   CTA without PE or aortic dissection but notable for small hematoma
   around minimally displaced left clavicular head fracture. Labs
   significant for EtOH level 270 and anion gap of 17. He also had a K of
   5.6 on a hemolyzed sample; given kayexalate. He was intermittently
   hypertensive and treated for EtOH withdrawal, receiving a total of
   valium 20mg IV and ativan 5mg IV along with banana bag x 1 L and NS IVF
   x 5 L. Also given Zofran for nausea, tylenol and morphine for pain. He
   was admitted to the MICU for further management. VS on transfer: T
   99.2, HR 97, BP 170/91 (ativan), RR 18, O2 98% 2LNC.
   .
   On the floor, pt reports continued left chest pressure with
   reproducible tenderness, worse on inspiration and cough. Anxiety and
   tremors currently improved with valium. Feels depressed but denies
   SI/HI. He reports multiple episodes of blacking out in setting of EtOH
   intoxication with only the prior noted admission for EtOH withdrawal;

   drink reportedly 24-36 hours prior to presentation to ED. Currently in
   withdrawal controlled with po valium. Pt reports not wanting to drink;
   has AA sponsor and wishes to return to outpatient program.
   - Valium 10mg prn for CIWA >10
   - MVI, thiamine, folate
   - Serum tox negative; urine tox ordered
   - SW consulted
   Chest pain: Most likely musculoskeletal given ecchymoses, TTP, and
   visualized clavicular fracture; pt does not recall fall but has been
   intoxicated from EtOH abuse. Constellation of nausea, diaphoresis, and
   shortness of breath concerning for cardiac etiology with EKG baseline
   with neg cardiac enzymes x 2. [**Month (only) 8**] be exacerbated by grief/adjustment
   disorder, ddx. panic attack. Could also be complicated by EtOH
   withdrawal.
   - F/u final CTA chest read
   - Cycle cardiac enzymes
   - EKG in AM
   - Management of fracture per Ortho recs
   - Management of EtOH withdrawal as above
   - Pain management as below
   - Psych consult

   in setting of daughter's death.
   - SW consulted and recommend psychiatric consult

   - Conservative management per Ortho curbside with sling, non weight
   bearing status in LUE
   - Monitor Hct

   management but given h/o pruritis, will switch to Fentanyl patch with
   Fentanyl boluses prn for breakthrough
   - Ortho consult to see today and staff in AM

   managed.
   - Given persistent pain and ecchymoses, will reimage
   - Sling as above
   - Resume ortho f/u and PT as outpatient

   This is a 68 y/o man with PMH notable for alcoholic cirrhosis admitted
   with abdominal pain/distension in setting of SMV thrombus and now
   transferred to MICU with hypotension/bradycardia and altered mental
   status.
   .
   # Hypotension/bradycardia: Improved after dosing of glucagon and likely
   related to decreased clearance of nadolol in setting of worsening renal
   failure. With hematocrit drop, also could be due to volume depletion
   with blood loss. Concern also for sepsis, but source unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 133**]
   investigate abdomen as potential source with CT abdomen/pelvis.
   Paracentesis on arrival to ICU not consistent with SBP.
   - redose glucagon prn, could add drip
   - repeat lactate once bps improved
   - hold all beta blockade
   - CT abdomen/pelvis to evaluate for bleeding source or ? colitis
   - follow blood cultures, paracentesis cultures
   .
   # Altered mental status: Could be related to hypotension or new
   infection (intraabdominal versus bacteremia). Appears to have been
   taking lactulose for past few days but hepatic encephalopathy certainly
   on the differential.
   - CT head without contrast
   - follow studies for SBP
   - hold lactulose for now (no NG tube due to recent banding of varices)
   - repeat RUQ ultrasound to eval for portal vein thrombosis
   .
   # Anemia: Hct down 10 points over 24 hours with hypotension. Has known
   varices with banding several days ago.
   - check hemolysis labs, Coombs test
   - hold all antihypertensives
   - 2 U PRBCs on arrival to the ICU
   - post-transfusion hct this afternoon
   - guaiac stools
   - CT abdomen/pelvis to eval for hemoperitoneum
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Concerning for hepatorenal syndrome. Urine lytes
   this morning with urine sodium < 10.
   - albumin 100 g daily X 2 days
   - consider midodrine/octreotide
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Improving since admission. Off of diuretics. Continue
   to trend.
   .
   # Alcoholic cirrhosis: MELD now 31 with today's labs. Recent SMV
   thrombosis on scan, with heparin gtt as described above, which is now
   off.
   - trend LFTs
   - continue lactulose, may need NG tube for dosing
   - RUQ ultrasound and CT abd/pelvis as above
   .
   # Type 2 DM: sliding scale insulin. while not eating, will need some
   lantus coverage (1/2 dose of 45 units given while eating).

   Imaging: 2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM [**10/2140**]:
   The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is markedly
   dilated. The right atrial pressure is indeterminate. There is mild
   symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size.
   Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). The right
   ventricular cavity is markedly dilated with depressed free wall
   contractility. There is abnormal systolic septal motion/position
   consistent with right ventricular pressure overload. The aortic valve
   leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present.
   The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral
   valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. Severe [4+]
   tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is severe pulmonary artery
   systolic hypertension. The pulmonic valve leaflets are thickened.
   Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of [**2140-5-13**], the right
   ventricle appears more dilated with severe pulmonary artery systolic
   hypertension.
   CARDIAC CATH [**2132**]:
   1. Selective coronary arteriography of this right dominant system
   revealed no significant coronary artery disease. The left main coronary
   artery was normal. The LAD, w/ two diagonal branches had no
   hemodynamically significant lesions. The LCx with a single major OM
   branch was normal. The dominant RCA also had no significant lesions.
   2. Left ventriculography revealed normal systolic function with a
   calculated ejection fraction of 77%.
   3. Resting hemodynamics revealed normal right sided filling pressures
   with a mean RA pressure of 9. There was moderate-to-severe pulmonary
   hypertension with RA pressures of 66/22. Left sided filling pressures
   were mildly elevated with an LVEPD of 20. Cardiac output was above
   normal with a cardiac index of 4.8. SVR was normal at 898, and PVR was
   mildly elevated at 142.
   4. Oxygen saturations revealed a large left-to-right shunt at the level
   of the RA with a step-up of 18% in oxygen saturation from calculated
   mixed venous to RA on 100% NRB. The calculated shunt volume was 17.2
   and the pulmonary/systemic flow ratio was 2.85.
   5. An atrial septal defect was crossed with the PA catheter and
   contrast injection into the left atrium revealed the large ASD w/
   left-to-right flow.
   6. On 100% NRB, the patients oxygenation improved significantly,
   although it did not reach 100% (peak=96%). This may have been due to
   actual inspiration of less than 100% O2 or a small right-to-left shunt.
   Q-eff was caclulated as virtually identical to Q-s, and therefore any
   right-to-left shunting was trivial.
   FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
   1. Coronary arteries are normal.
   2. Normal ventricular function.
   3. Large left-to-right shunt via large atrial septal defect.
   4. Moderate-to-severe pulmonary hypertension
   ECG: A-paced, LAD, interventricular conduction delay, non-specific ST
   twave changes

   80F w/ pmh chronic diastolic CHF p/w dyspnea.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 40F with stage IIIB breast cancer with progression to
   brain mets who presented with dyspnea and a large pericardial effusion
   + tamponade physiology. She is now s/p pericardioscentesis with
   drainage of 500mL of a serosanguinous fluid and improvement of her
   symptoms. She remains persistently tachycardic.
   .
   #. Pericardial effusion: Given her history of advanced breast cancer
   this is likely a malignant effusion. Infection is a distant
   possibility. Signs of pericardial tamponade were seen on initial echo
   with improvement of hemodynamics and no residual effusion after tap. Of
   note, she has not been exposed to anthracyclines or recent XRT to the
   chest wall.
   - Continue to monitor vital signs
   - Follow output from pericardial drain
   - Repeat ECHO in the AM to evaluate for recurrence of effusion
   - Repeat CXR in the AM
   - Fluid chemistries consistent with a serosanguinous exudate
   - Fluid cytology pending. CBC of fluid has 60% "other" cells that are
   non-lymphoid and likely represent malignant clones. Cell count is
   [**Numeric Identifier 828**]/uL.
   - Fluid Gram stain negative for microorgs. Cultures pending
   - Consider pericardial window for recurrence of effusion
   .
   #. Pneumonia: Pt with recent diagnosis of PNA at OSH based on
   persistent low grade fevers, SOB, cough, and LUL infiltrate on CXR. On
   day [**3-26**] of treatment with azithromycin.
   - Complete azithromycin course
   - Repeat CXR as above
   - Blood cultures pending
   .
   #. Breast cancer: Stage IIIB, ER/PR/HER2 tripple negative with
   progression to metastatic disease. Of note, tumor was large and
   approached the chest wall. She was treated with neoadjuvant
   cyclophosphamide and taxotere, surgery, and XRT to the chest wall. She
   subsequently developed brain mets without evidence of leptomeningeal
   carcinomatosis. She is s/p recent brain XRT and steroids for edema.
   - Update med onc that patient is in house in the AM. Input appreciated.
   - Continue symptomatic control of pain, nausea as needed
   - No acute intervention at this time
   .
   #. Tachycardia: Likely compensatory from tamponade physiology, toxic
   metabolic state, and volume depletion from recent poor PO intake.
   - Low Na on admission consistent with hypovolemia.
   - Replete fluids PRN. Received 4L prior to transfer to the CCU.
   - Consider the possibility of pulmonary embolism given this is a
   hypercoaguable patient. Since she is not a candidate for systemic
   anticoagulation in the context of potentially hemorrhagic brain mets
   and bloody pericardial effusion, we will hold off on further workup for
   now.
   .
   #. Hyponatremia: Given clinicl picture of poor PO intake for several
   days, persistent tachycardia, and hyponatremia this is most likely
   consistent with hypovolemia. DD includes siADH from a CNS or lung
   process.
   - Replete fluids as above
   - Ulytes pre-renal
   - Hyponatremia improved with IVF
   .
   #. FEN: Normal diet. Replete electrolytes PRN
   .
   #. Access:  PIV
   .
   #. PPx: Heparin SQ, no need for GI PPx for now
   .
   #. Code:  FULL
   .
   #. Dispo:  CCU for now pending above
   .

   HPI:
   Mr. [**Known lastname 5574**] is an 84 yo man with a high-grade cardiac B-cell
   lymphoma for which he is now undergoing R-[**Hospital1 988**] chemotherapy and a
   history of COPD, DVT s/p IVC filter, and pneumonia with
   respiratory failure requiring endotracheal intubation in [**2-27**]. Today is

   admission from [**Date range (1) 6761**]. He received Neulasta on [**4-10**].  following
   his discharge, he has been feeling generally well; however, he admits
   to increasing exertional dyspnea overthe past 2-3 days. He explains
   that very light activity, such as changing his clothes or walking short
   distances, has resulted in significant shortness of breath. He denies
   cough, sputum production, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and
   swelling/pain of the arms or legs. He admits to low-grade fevers today;
   while visiting, his daughter noted that he had a temperature of 100.4
   degrees. For this reason, he was advised to report to the Emergency
   Room for evaluation.
   Upon arrival in the Emergency Department, had temperature of 99.6
   degrees. He was tachycardic to 118 and tachypneic (RR 30-40) with
   oxygen saturations of 95% on room air. During the first several
   minutesof is Emergency Department course, he developed rapidly
   increasing work of breathing. A CXR demonstrated no evidence
   ofpneumonia or effusion; furthermore, an echocardiogram showed no
   pericardial effusion. He was noted to have a WBC of 8.8 with 26%
   neutrophils and 36% bands. Due to progressive respiratorydistress
   without hypoxia, he was started on BiPAP. In addition, he was given IV
   solumderol 125mg, ASA 325mg, bronchodilators, piperacillin-tazobactam,

   # Altered Mental Status:  Unclear etiology.  No evidence of infection,
   with out pneumonia on CXR, no fevers/chills, negative UA.  Drugs may
   play a role: levaquin is notorious, he also takes oxycodone, so
   influence of narcotics also may be at play.  Patient has mild ARF (up
   to 2.2, resolved by day after admission), so may also be a component
   (increasing toxicity of neurontin). Patient is reaching for objects
   that are not there and he may be having myoclonic jerks. history of
   fall, so will hold on NCHCT.
   - hold levofloxacin
   - hold narcotics if possible
   - IVF
   - f/u blood and urine culture
   .
   #. Hypoxia:  Unclear etiology.  Likely chronic, given elevated HCO3. No
   clinical evidence of pneumonia.  CXR w/o consolidation, no symptoms of
   cough or fevers, and no leukocytosis; but is also vaguely suggestive of
   a primary pleural process (pleural plaques), possibly mesothelioma.
   Patient does have a history of dCHF, but no pulmonary edema on CXR,
   flat JVP, and dry MM.  PE unlikely in the absence of tachycardia, EKG
   changes.
   - ABG for AA gradient
   - wean O2 as tolerated
   - consider chest CT to better characterize
   .
   #. Transient Hypotension: Resolved. The patient had one episode of
   hypotension in the ED with systolic pressures of 80. The patient
   received only 2L NS with resolution of the hypotension. Given his mild
   acute renal failure, likely this is related to hypovolemia. Dry mucous
   membranes on exam.  No clinical evidence of pneumonia by symptoms, CXR,
   or [**Last Name (LF) 14444**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] low suspicion of septic etiology

   - Volume resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins

   - cont ASA/plavix
   - pt w/ lipitor allergy.

   acute on chronic renal failure. Will continue aspirin and plavix as
   above. The patient has a history of bradycardia, which is likely why he

 she was

Chief Complaint:  Resipratory Distress
   HPI:
   History of Present Illness:  This is a 68 year old gentleman with h/o
   CAD, DM2, HTN, hep C who presents with 4 days of productive cough and
   shortness of breath.  He reports that beginning 4 days ago, he
   developed cough productive of yellow/brown sputum which has worsened
   over this time period.  He notes shortness of breath worsening in this
   setting.  He endorses chills, but denies subjective fevers.  He also
   reports anterior chest pain with coughing and worse with deep
   inspiration.
   .
   In addition, over the past several days he has had profuse watery
   diarrhea which has slowed yesterday and no episodes today.  He reports
   he noted "specks of blood" in his stool when the diarrhea was heavy.
   He reports stool was dark in color, not black; he has not been taking
   his iron.  He also reports N/V and throwing up "black specks", no
   bright red blood, but this too has resolved.  He denies abdominal pain.
   .
   In the ED, initial vs were: T 100.7 P 108 BP 100/60 RR 20 O2 sat
   85%RA-->100%NRB.  CXR demonstrated a diffuse patchy opacity in the
   right lower lobe consistent with pneumonia with a possible second focus
   of pneumonia at the left lung base versus atelectasis.  There was also
   question of accompanying right parapneumonic effusion.  On exam he had
   guaic negative brown stool.  He received 2L NS and 1L  with 40meq KCL.
   Additionally, he received 750mg IV levofloxacin.  He was written for
   40meq PO KCL x2, but he did not tolerate the doses.
   .
   Patient is recently s/p ICU stay where he was continued on levaquin
   with steady improvement in his oxygenation.  Was called out to floor on
   3L NC.  On floor, triggered for hypoxia today with O2 requirement of 5L
   NC.  Aggressive suctioning, nebs, and chest PT was attempted.  This
   evening, patient was observed to be eating and aspirate on his meal.
   Thereafter desaturated to mid-80's on 100% NRB.  ICU transfer was
   initiated.
   .
   On arrival to ICU patient was chest pain free, requesting pain
   medications for LE neuropathy after transfer.  Patient not notably
   dyspneic, but desaturating to 70's on room air, 80's with speaking or
   removing his oxygenation.  ABG on floor prior to transfer 7.38/54/59/33
   on NRB.  Patient placed on BiPap - and satting 100% when wearing, but
   refusing to wear.  Then with repeated episodes of desaturation to
   mid-80's on NRB.  Patient was intubated.

   Patient is a 89 y/o M with a PMH of CVA in [**2143**] with residual
   disordered breathing, DM type 2 presenting with four days of
   intermittent anterior chest discomfort and new hypoxia
   .
   #. Chest Pain - The pt presents with hx of anterior chest discomfort
   occuring at rest for several days, similar to previous episodes which
   occurred during exercise. ECG with new RBBB and ST depressions
   throughout precordium. Symptoms are concerning for cardiac vs pulmonary
   etiology. Cardiac enzymes negative X2, D-dimer elevated.  TIMI score 3
   for age, RF and ST changes giving a 13% risk at 14 days of: all-cause
   mortality, new or recurrent MI, or severe recurrent ischemia requiring
   urgent revascularization. However given concurrent hypoxia, elevated
   D-dimer, and new RBBB also concern for PE.
   - Continue IV heparin
   - Continue Aggrenox
   - Continue lisinopril 2.5 mg daily
   - Trend CE - negative X2
   - Pt currently does not want to pursue cardiac catheterization, would
   consider stress testing following rule out of PE, improvement of
   hypoxia
   - Will start pre-contrast hydration for consideration of CTA this am
   .
   #. Hypoxia - The patient with hypoxia requiring NRB, currently weaned
   to 5L NC, no clear evidence of volume overload on exam. Pt has history
   of disordered breathing following stroke, has been off CPAP, also
   history of tobacco use, likely has underlying lung disease. Concern for
   PE as described above
   - Continue O2 NC to maintain sat >88%
   - Discuss risk/benefit of CTA to rule out PE, if no CTA would pursue
   non-contrast Chest CT
   .
   #. Hx of CVA - resulting complex disordered breathing - pt has refused
   further treatment with CPAP or home O2 as outpatient
   - continue aggrenox
   .
   #. HTN - continue lisinopril
   .
   #. Type 2 diabetes - hold metformin while in house, start insulin SS
   .
   #. Hypothyroidism - continue synthroid
   .
   #. FEN - NPO pending additional CE, then will start cardiac diet
   .
   #. Access:  PIV
   .
   #. PPx:  PPI, heparin gtt
   .
   #. Code:  Full
   .
   #. Dispo:  ICU
   .

   # Severe Sepsis: Patient with fever and hematuria meets SIRS criteria
   with fever, hypotension, and 8% bands on OSH labs.  Likely source is
   prostatitis from biopsy and/or recent instrumentation.
   - Central venous line
   - Attempt A-line
   - IV fluids to goal CVP 8-12, currently [**7-18**] s/p 8 L fluid
   - Transfuse for Hct > 21
   - IV fluid boluses and neosynephrine if needed to maintain MAP > 60 and
   UOP > 30cc/hr
   - Follow-up blood, urine cultures from OSH
   - Send blood and urine cultures now
   - Trend WBC count and fever curve
   - Broad coverage with Zosyn and Ciprofloxacin for anti-pseudomonal
   coverage and GNR coverage
   - Repeat lactate overnight
   .
   # Transaminitis: Elevated AST/ALT on admission labs. No others to
   compare prior to these. Consider liver derangements [**1-10**] sepsis.
   - trend LFTs
   .
   # Acute hematocrit drop: Hct 37.7 at OSH to 29.4. This may be
   dilutional; however, argument against this is WBC increased from 6.9 to
   9.0.  No active signs of GI bleeding, but patient states that he had
   some blood-streaked stool s/p biopsy
   - guiaic all stools
   - check Hct again in AM

 severe

BP stable 100-110, NSR 60s-80s with PVCs noted; lytes repleted; autodiuresed this shift, putting out 300-770 per hour for several hours - serum sodium remains stable at 142 (129 in lab reports is grossly lipemic and inaccurate) - UA/urine lytes sent. Urine output currently tapering off. NGT placed in L nare, placement confirmed via CXR; NPO except meds; insulin SS; skin intact; 2 sets of blood cultures sent for increasing WBC; T max this shift 100.3. Wife called earlier in shift, was very worried, nursing reassured her and she will likely visit this morning.

PLAN: Pt will return to OR on Monday for his L lung total bronch lavage; later this AM per MICU attending, will shut off propofol, do another SBT and if he does well he will be extubated.

s/110
s.  Given labetalol 20mg iv x 2 and

s.    Increase clonidine patch

   PRN dilaudid or Tylenol for pain.

   75 y/oF with T Cell Lymphoma with CNS involvment with recurrent status
   epilepticus, non-convulsive, transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for further
   management. Phenobarbital is indicated, and we have discussed with
   neurology on call, pharmacy, and anesthesia regarding elective
   intubation for phenobarbital management, airway protection. Have also
   discussed this with the son, who is okay with trial on intubation and
   phenobarb. Risks of intubation have been discussed with the family.

   weight). BMT fellow paged to be made aware of this decision, reached
   with resident, RN, pharmacy, and intensivist overnight.

   corrected dilantin was 15.6.  Aiming for between 16-18, will re-bolus

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:  Respiratory failure
   HPI:
   A 54 year-old female with history of alcohol abuse, status post
   splenectomy, status post multiple abdominal surgeries initially
   presenting with altered mental status. The patient's mother states that
   the patient had been on an alcohol binge for a few days without
   significant PO intake. She has been complaining of poorly localized
   abdominal pain over the past few weeks, but did not complain about
   worsening. The mother was checking on her during the day early this
   morning found the patient complaining of difficulty breathing. The
   patient subsequently became confused and was not responding
   appropriately to questions. The mother called EMS to bring the patient
   to the ED, and she was noted to be obtunded in the ambulance.
   On arrival to the ED at 04:23, vitals were T 96.9 HR 121 BP 82/48 RR 20
   SaO2 99%RA, FSG 18. The patient was given at least 2 amps D50 with
   improvement in mental status. At 07:20, the patient subsequently
   complained of fatigue/malaise with her nurse in the room and became
   unresponsive. The patient was asystolic. During the code the patient
   received epinephrine x 7, atropine x 3, calcium x 2, magnesium x 2,
   narcan x 2. A femoral line was placed and the patient was given 2-4L of
   saline. She was coded for 26 minutes, with final return of a perfusing
   rhythm with pulses 07:56.

   A 54 year-old female with history of alcohol abuse, status post
   splenectomy, status post multiple abdominal surgeries initially
   presenting with altered mental status and dyspnea, with subsequent
   asystolic arrest for 26 minutes and multiple laboratory abnormalities,
   including significant bandemia, metabolic acidosis, and elevated
   lactate.
   * Status post arrest: The patient had a 26 minute asystolic arrest in
   the ED. The most likely etiologies are acidosis versus potential toxin
   ingestion. The patient was no longer hypoglycemic at the time of
   arrest. Her examination at this time is significant for minimally
   responsive dilated pupils, negative gag reflex, decerebrate posturing,
   no response to pain. The length of the code suggests a poor prognosis.
   - Initiate cooling protocol
   - EEG
   - Stat CT head when feasible
   - Neurology consult; appreciate
   - Treatment for potential underlying etiologies as below
   * Anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient has renal failure, a
   significant lactic acidosis, as well as ketones likely due to
   dehydration. Her osmolar gap initially was only 11, however increased
   to 17 on repeat testing, of unclear etiology. Acidosis is improving a
   bicarbonate drip.
   - IVF hydration
   - Continue bicarbonate drip
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - Toxicology consult; appreciate
   - Evaluation for sepsis as below
   * Sepsis: Unclear etiology - patient is status post splenectomy and
   therefore immunocompromised. Initial laboratories significant for WBC
   12.9 with 32% bandemia. Concern for catastrophic abdominal event given
   gas distended bowel loops and recent complaints of abdominal pain.
   Initial chest x-ray and urinalysis without infection.
   - Antibiosis with vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and metronidazole to treat
   likely abdominal process
   - Stat CT torso
   - Blood, sputum, urine, stool cultures pending
   - Surgery following; appreciate
   * Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia to the 140s. Unclear etiology
   patient now febrile; also concerning for sepsis, hypovolemia, and
   alcohol withdrawal.
   - Tylenol
   - IVF hydration
   - Consider benzodiazepine for alcohol withdrawal
   * Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Intubated initially in the setting of
   a code.
   - Continue supportive ventilation with goal to compensate for her
   profound metabolic acidosis from a ventilatory standpoint
   * Acute renal failure: Initially appears pre-renal in the setting of
   poor PO and FeNa 0.4. The patient may progress to ATN in the setting of
   hypotension.
   - IVF hydration
   - Continue to monitor
   * Anemia: The patient
s baseline hematocrit is 32 and was 25 on
   admission. Hematocrit has now dropped to 21, likely in the setting of
   dilution.  Hemolysis labs negative. Guaiac negative on admission.
   - Guaiac all stools

   * EtoH abuse: Concern for alcohol withdrawal as above.

   * Hypoglycemia: Unclear etiology. The patient had recently been

MICU NPN Admit note

77y/o male who presents with mental status changes.  This past week pt's family reports increse in lethargy,confusion, and garbled speech.  Pt was seen by PCP and he was sent for CT which was negative for bleed.  This morning, pt's son found him to be minimally responsive, confused, and incontinent of bowels and bladder. In EW, pt was given 2L NS fluid bolus (lactate 3.5), levoquin, lactulose, Blood and urine sent for culture.  Pt transferred to MICU for further management.

PMH: CHF, Interstitial Fibrosis

NKDA

Neuro: Upon arrival to MICU, pt confused and oriented to person only.  He remains oriented x 1 but is having moments of lucidity more often.  Initially, Speech garbled although seems to be clearing.  Pt follows commands consistantly. Lactulose being given for confusion. urine tox screen sent and negative. Per Son, [**Name (NI) **], Pt is usually oriented, drives, and does self ADLs.

Resp: Pt h/o interstitial fibrosis on home O2. Pt on 2L NC here satting 98%.  LS CTA.

CV: HR 60's. NSR, no ectopy noted.  BP 141-165/57-59.  PO lopresser given.  Echo ordered.  Hct 36.6%. Plts 65 (trending down).  NS infusing @ 80cc/hr x 2 liters.

GI: NPO except ice chips. NGT in place and confirmed by CXr and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 5452**].  Meds being given via NGT but if pt appears more awake would give them PO.  Pt being given lactulose. 1 Medium BM, guiac negative. Pt was able to ask for bedpan.  pt being w/u for liver failure. Abdomenal US done. Results pnding.  Heptalogy following.  hepatitis panels sent and pnding.

GU: urine output tapering off.

ID: urine positive for nitrates and bacteria. Pt to start on ciprofloxacin when available from pharmacy.  Lactate down to 2.3.

Skin: Rt upper arm with large skin tear.  Wound cleanser nad allovyn dressing placed. Site is bleeding. Left upper arm and elbow with skin tear.  Pt also appears to be bleeding from urethra.

Social: Lives at home independently with wife who has alzheimers dz.  Son, [**Name (NI) **], is the spokesperson (he does not think pt has HCP filled out).  Phone # of son on [**Name2 (NI) **] board in pt's room.

Dispo: Remain in MICU. Full code

Nausea / vomiting
   Assessment:
   Pt experiencing nausea & retching with dangling on edge of bed;
   activity associated with elevated HR (>100 NST & BP 130/systolic). No
   vomiting occurred.
   Action:

   Response:
   Nausea & retching resolved after Zofran and with time. Pt tolerated
   return to bed without recurrence of nausea.
   Plan:

   Tracheal reconstruction (Tracheobronchial)
   Assessment:
   Pt awake, alert, oriented x3, MAEs. NSR with some PVC activity; BP with
   MAP >60 on phenylephrine @ 1.2mcg/kg/min.  Urine output is adequate
   with IVF @ 80cc hour.  Lung sounds notable for persistent scattered
   rhonchus. Resp rate & pattern are wnl; no c/o distress expressed. O2
   saturations remain mid 90s on NC weaned to 2L. Right thoractotomy
   incision with derma bond closure- dry & intact. CT x2 on right to 10cm
   dry suction with serosanginous drainage; +fluctuations; no air leak
   detected; no crepitus. Pt with congested nonproductive cough.
   Action:
   Neuro checks & hemodynamic monitoring per ICU routine. Neo weaned as
   tolerated.
   PRN Albuterol nebs and mucomist nebs provided; CPT; incentive
   spirometer; coughing & deep breathing exercises done. Position changes
   Q 2-3 hours. Humidified oxygen provided prn.
   CT assessed Q 2 hour & prn
   Response:
   Neuro status unchanged. BP drift to MAP <50 with Neo at .6mcg/kg/min,
   so dose increased to .8mcg/kg/min with MAP >60. Urine output remains
   adequate. Lung sounds remain coarse with scattered rhonchi & exp
   wheezes. Pt has strong congested cough that remains nonproductive, but
   she feels improvement with neb therapy. Saturations remains >94%.  CT
   drainage is more sanguineous; moderate to large amount of drainage
   continues from [**Doctor Last Name **] tube site requiring dressing changes x2 today.
   Plan:
   Continue with above assessments. Cont with pulmonary toileting &
   bronchodilator/mucomist therapy; cont to encourage IS & C, DB
   activities; cont OOB as tolerated.
   Wean neo as tolerated.
   Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)
   Assessment:
   No c/o of pain at rest; [**1-30**] right chest/flank pain with movement &
   coughing. Epidural of APS 10 (dilaludid/bupivicaine) infusing at 6cc
   hour. Pt c/o intermittent itching at back of head/neck.
   Action:
   Pain assessed Q 4 hour & prn; epidural site assessed with turns.
   Pt OOB to chair
   Response:
   Pain exacerbated with activity & coughing to [**4-29**] over right anterior
   chest that increased with deep breathing. APS rate increased to 8cc
   hour with improved pain control. Epidural site wnl with small amount of
   stable bloody ooze under transparent dressing. Sensory level @ costal
   margin; no motor deficit. Pt tolerated OOB activity with minimal assist
   of 2. No rash, redness or hives noted at site of itching; no further
   complaints this afternoon.
   Plan:
   Continue Q4 hour & prn pain assessment; monitor epidural site. Monitor
   for allergic response(pt with h/o multiple allergies, some to
   narcotic).

   of COPD vs possible restrictive disease given her CXR.  Regardless, she
   has developed worsening hypercarbic respiratory failure likely due to
   atelectasis, deconditioning and a possible new PNA.  She does not
   appear to be volume overloaded at this time.

   - Obtain further records/history in AM
   #. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status is likely
   secondary to her hypercarbia, with possible contribution from infection
   and hypoglycemia.  As we have corrected these underlying conditions her
   mental status is clearing.  Head CT negative, no focal abnormalities on
   neuro exam.

   Assessment and Plan
   84 yo female presents with syncopal episode and multiple melanotic
   stools.
   .
   #Syncope: Multiple possible etiologies including vasovagal, arrythmia,
   or hypoglycemia, although history is not particularly suggestive for
   any of these. Suspect that if pt has had some ongoing GI bleeding,
   particularly in the setting of abd pain, this could have resulted in
   transient hypotension.
   -monitor on tele
   -aggressive managment of possible GI bleeding as below
   -monitor for evidence of recurrence
   -consider echo before discharge
   .
   #Melanotic stools: Concering for GI bleeding, potentially from upper
   source given pt's prior h/o PUD.
   -[**Hospital1 7**] IV PPI
   -two large bore IVs
   -q6 hr HCTs
   -hold home ASA, atenolol
   -transfuse for HCT <30
   -EGD with GI in AM
   .
   #Abd pain: Ddx includes pain from GIB, bowel ischemia or coronary
   ischemia.
   -ROMI
   -consider CTA abd if clinically worsening but will defer for now given
   renal failure
   .
   #Leukocytosis: Likely stress demargination but bowel ischemia also a
   consideration. No other clear source and thus far afebile.
   -monitor for now, plan as above
   .
   #RF: Pt's Cr is above level in [**2184**] but unclear how far off she is from
   recent baseline. Has received 1L fluid in ED; continue gentle
   hydreation PRN and trend.
   .
   #CAD: Holding ASA and BB in setting of probable acute bleed. Plan to
   re-add as soon as possible. Continue Zetia.
   .
   #HTN: Holding home atenolol. Will monitor for now and treat as needed.
   .
   #Depression/psych: Continue home meds.
   .
   #Hypothyroid: Continue home levothyroxine.

   - monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Cryptococcal Meningitis: Headaches have resolved completely. previous
   elevated opening pressures, now stablized. Last LP showed decreased
   pressure with elevated WBC but no organisms so far on gram stain or
   culture. The CSF crypto titer >1:64 but this is expected as it may
   change in 2 weeks. Patient is clinically asymptomatic with perfect
   clinical picture and no growth on cultures.
   - appreciate ID following patient.
   - plan to repeat LP w/ opening pressure [**11-16**], last dose 10/17
   - cont flucytosine 1500mg PO q6 (day11), ambisone 400mg IV q24h (day
   [**12-15**]).
   - follow LFTs
   - cont toradol 30mg IV q8 ATC and dilaudid 2mg q3IV prn with bowel
   regimen, zofran and ativan q6 ATC and compazine prn
   .
   # HIV, previously on HAART, but off X 3 months [**3-4**] dysphagia/vomiting
   as well as noncompliance per OSH HIV doctor. No h/o AIDS defining
   illnesses until now.
   -VL 100K, CD4 count is 116, which is higher than expected for someone
   with crypo meningitis
   - treating crypto meningitis as above, will need flucon after
   - started bactrim DS qd proph per ID - switched to liquid formulation.
   -will defer to his outpt HIV MDs regarding restarting ART.
   .
   # Hypomagnesemia: Replete as above, Mg sulfate IV 4gm q 4 hrs until
   repleted.
   .
   # Dysphagia X 3 months, intermittent, with liquids and solids/pills a/w
   pain (during episodes only) and vomiting. No odynophagia. s/p EGD and
   barium swallow 1 month ago, unremarkable. Mostly issues with swallowing
   pills.
   - has been tolerating some of oral meds here, main one is flucytosine.
   not tolerating bactrim (too big), ok with liquid formulation
   - hold on GI consult inpatient unless acute issue, he has GI f/u
   .
   # Depression: Continue seroquel 25 mg qhs.
   .
   # Tobacco abuse: Declining nicotine patch
   .
   # FEN/proph: monitor lytes as above, gen diet as tolerated, TEDs/SCDs,
   no need for PPI, bowel regimen, will ask for PICC placement for easier
   access.
   .

Chief Complaint:  Pericardial effusion s/p SVT ablation
   HPI:
   66-year-old lady with history of breast and bladder cancers was
   admitted for elective EPS with ablation for SVT.  She first noted
   palpitations approximately 16 years ago in the setting of high
   emotional distress when her son was killed while in the service.
   Since then, she has had palpitations in the setting of
   chemotherapy, and over the past years has had no more than [**3-2**]
   episodes per year. However, on the day of her most recent
   cystoscopy on [**3-5**] at [**Hospital1 5791**], she
   experienced a tachycardia, which was terminated after she
   received intravenous Lopressor. The same tachycardia occurred on
   [**3-9**] for which she presented to [**Hospital6 3851**]
   Emergency Room, where the tachycardia was terminated with
   intravenous adenosine. The tracings of the tachycardia were reviewed by
   her Electrophysiologist, Dr.[**Last Name (STitle) 5758**], and thought be a narrow
   complex tachycardia at 150 beats/minute with an RP interval of 100-120
   msec. However, immediately post adenosine, there was evidence of sinus
   rhythm with a fully pre-excited QRS complex consistent with a
   left lateral bypass tract. Since the Emergency Room visit, she
   has been on low-dose atenolol without further recurrences of the
   arrhythmia. Dr.[**Last Name (STitle) 9963**] recommended EPS with ablation and the
   patient was admitted today for the procedure.
   .
   During the procedure she developed hypotension to SBP of 77 mm HG.
   This responded to IVF and dopamine infusion to SBP of 130s.  Patient
   was mentating appropriately.  Focal views of TTE showed
   noncircumferential pericardial effusion with mild RA collapse without
   RV collapse.  Her heparin was reversed with protamine.  PA
   catheterization showed preserved CO, no equalization of filling
   pressures, and preserved Y descent on RA tracing.  This suggested
   nonhemodynamically significant effusion.  Patient was admitted to CCU
   with PA catheter for close hemodynamic monitoring.
   .
   On arrival patient complained of stable pleuritic chest pain which she
   had since the cath lab.  She denied any shortness of breath.  No other
   complaints.
   .
   REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: The patient denies fever, chills, headaches, blurred
   vision, constipation, nausea, vomitting, shortness of breath, PND,
   orhtopnea, lower extremity edema.  No history of pulmonary embolus,
   DVT, stroke, melena, BRBPR, blood in urine.
   .
